title: Lesson 7: Mitochondria, Chloroplasts and Endosymbiosis
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Exploring mitochondria and chloroplasts as energy-converting organelles. Understanding endosymbiotic theory evidence including double membranes, circular DNA, and 70S ribosomes.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the structure of mitochondria (cristae, matrix) and chloroplasts (thylakoids, stroma).
Students can identify evidence supporting the endosymbiotic theory (double membrane, own DNA, 70S ribosomes).
Students can distinguish between organelles of the endomembrane system (ER, Golgi, lysosomes) and energy-converting organelles (mitochondria, chloroplasts).

syllabusLinks.module: Module 1: Cells as the Basis of Life
syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can draw and label mitochondria and chloroplasts showing their double membranes.
I can list three pieces of evidence that mitochondria were once free-living bacteria.
I can explain why mitochondria are called 'semi-autonomous.'

prerequisites.description: Prokaryotic structure: 70S ribosomes, circular DNA, size 1–10 µm, no nucleus

engagementHook.title: The Cells Within Cells
engagementHook.content: Show Paramecium bursaria (ciliate with green algal endosymbionts living inside). 'This is endosymbiosis happening now. But 1.5 billion years ago, something similar created the power plants of all complex life.' Show TEM of mitochondrion next to Rickettsia bacterium—they look identical. 'Why do your mitochondria look like bacteria? Today we solve that mystery.'

keyConcepts.definition: Double membrane (outer smooth, inner folded into cristae). Matrix contains DNA and 70S ribosomes. Site of aerobic respiration (ATP production). Found in almost all eukaryotic cells.
Double membrane. Contain thylakoids (stacked into grana) and stroma (fluid). Contain DNA and 70S ribosomes. Site of photosynthesis. Found in plants and algae.

Mitochondria and chloroplasts evolved from free-living prokaryotes engulfed by ancestral eukaryotic cells. Evidence: (1) Double membrane (engulfing), (2) Own circular DNA (like bacteria), (3) 70S ribosomes (like bacteria), (4) Size similar to bacteria, (5) Reproduce by binary fission.
These organelles have their own DNA and ribosomes but depend on the nucleus for most proteins. They can reproduce independently within the cell.

misconceptions.misconception: Mitochondria and chloroplasts are part of the endomembrane system
misconceptions.correction: Explicitly state they are NOT derived from ER/Golgi (Lesson 5). They have different origins (endosymbiosis vs. budding).
Separate events. Mitochondria evolved from purple bacteria (aerobic); chloroplasts from cyanobacteria (photosynthetic). Mitochondria came first.
They need nuclear genes for most functions—hence 'semi-autonomous,' not fully autonomous.

items: Single (nuclear envelope double but different origin)

contentSections.title: Semi-Autonomous Nature
contentSections.content: These organelles have their own DNA and ribosomes but depend on the nucleus for most proteins. They can reproduce independently within the cell through binary fission.
contentSections.example: Mitochondria replicate when cells need more energy (muscle training increases mitochondrial number).

multipleChoice.question: Which feature of mitochondria provides evidence that they evolved from free-living bacteria?
multipleChoice.rationale: Evidence from Lesson 1 prokaryotic structure. 70S ribosomes and circular DNA are bacterial traits.

multipleChoice.question: The inner membrane of a mitochondrion is folded into cristae to:
options: Increase surface area for energy production
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Increase surface area for energy production
multipleChoice.rationale: Structure-function relationship. Cristae increase surface area for ATP synthesis during cellular respiration.

multipleChoice.question: Chloroplasts and mitochondria are described as 'semi-autonomous' because they:
options: Have their own DNA and ribosomes but depend on the nucleus for most proteins
Are part of the endomembrane system
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Have their own DNA and ribosomes but depend on the nucleus for most proteins
multipleChoice.rationale: Definition of semi-autonomous. They have some independence but rely on nuclear genes for most functions.

shortAnswer.question: Outline three pieces of evidence that support the theory that mitochondria evolved from free-living prokaryotic cells. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Contain circular DNA (similar to bacteria, not linear like nucleus)
1 mark: Contain 70S ribosomes (similar to prokaryotes, different from eukaryotic 80S)
1 mark: Surrounded by double membrane (suggests engulfing by host cell) OR reproduce by binary fission (like bacteria) OR similar size to bacteria
shortAnswer.commonError: Mentioning 'have DNA' without specifying circular; saying 'have ribosomes' without specifying 70S.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between mitochondria and chloroplasts in terms of their function and the organisms in which they are found. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Mitochondria carry out aerobic respiration (ATP production) in animal and plant cells; Chloroplasts carry out photosynthesis in plant cells (and algae)
1 mark: Mitochondria found in most eukaryotes; Chloroplasts only in plants/algae (not animal cells)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying mitochondria are only in animals.

definitions: Mitochondria have double membranes and cristae; site of aerobic respiration (ATP production).
Chloroplasts have double membranes and thylakoids; site of photosynthesis.
Both contain circular DNA and 70S ribosomes (like bacteria).
Evidence suggests they evolved from free-living prokaryotes (endosymbiotic theory).
They are semi-autonomous (have own DNA but need nuclear genes too).
keyPoints: Cristae = folded inner membrane for ATP synthesis
diagrams: Mitochondrion cross-section with labeled cristae and matrix

shortAnswer: Three pieces of evidence supporting the endosymbiotic theory are: (1) Mitochondria contain circular DNA similar to bacteria, not linear DNA like the nucleus; (2) They contain 70S ribosomes which are the same size as prokaryotic ribosomes, not 80S like eukaryotic cytoplasmic ribosomes; (3) They are surrounded by a double membrane, which suggests the ancestral host cell engulfed a prokaryote. Additional evidence includes that they reproduce by binary fission like bacteria and are similar in size to bacteria.

Mitochondria carry out aerobic respiration to produce ATP and are found in most eukaryotic cells including both animals and plants. Chloroplasts carry out photosynthesis to produce glucose and are only found in plant cells and some algae, not in animal cells. Both organelles have double membranes and their own DNA.
